reviews.review_msg: Took this in Spring 2020. Super chill class. I enjoyed her teaching style (very straightforward) and she's really nice.

He showed the Raid and John Wick movie action scenes in class, then step by step analyzed how the Indonesian Pensak Silat martial art has become globalized through films. Amazing! Also, learned that Wonder Woman was co-produced with a Chinese film giant that also owns majority share of AMC theatres in the US. Wow!

I had Fen for 348, 444 and 240.  She is a wonderful professor with a lot of knowledge about the political economy of communications.  A lot of students couldn't grasp the political theory involved and complained, too bad, not the easiest material to deal with.  She made the material easy to understand and and was always willing to clarify concepts.
Had her in Spring 2020. Easy class. She was really straightforward with her lecture. I am a fan of her teaching style.

Great teacher overall and he is always available to help when needed. His grading scale is higher than usual communications grading however he marks easier to it. You should come prepared to class by doing readings. His slides are really informative and useful, it is really easy to understand too. I love this class so much and would def retake it

He's awesome! Super funny and kind. Has a thick accent but you get used to it. He speaks English fluently so there is no "language barrier." He's also a very prolific scholar always publishing pieces relevant to the courses he teaches (in English AND Korean). He's also very helpful and wants students to succeed. He doesn't do email very well though

Professor Jin is awesome! He is a really nice, a great marker, and can be quite generous, CMNS 348 was an easy class to do well in, and achieve a high mark with some effort. As mentioned before, he has an accent, which I was worried about at first, but after the first couple of weeks you become use to it and he is easy to understand. Take it!

I really liked Dal's class. The accent can be hard to get used to at first but it's fine after the first few classes. You definitely have to attend, but the format is engaging and he's an extremely fair marker. If you do the work an A should be achievable. He also assigns his own readings and he's extremely knowledgable.

Jin was one of the best prof I encountered at SFU. He does have an accent, but he always emphases his points and his PPTs are uploaded every week. (Around week3, I got used to the accent). Attendance is a must. Midterm was easy. Jin is very knowledgable on the subject and he is also a very democratic prof. He genuinely cares about students.

Jin was a great prof! At times his accent was a bit hard to understand but he always repeated the important points more than once and he put his slides up every week so I never had any problem with that. He is very passionate about what he teaches and has a great sense of humor! Just make sure you're always on time, he doesn't like late-comers.

He uses perfect English but his thick accent makes it hard to understand him at first. He's very friendly, smiles often, and his materials were interesting. He started posting lecture notes online too which is awesome. He even wrote some of the assigned readings himself (as he's a writer too).

He's very hard to understand. Honestly not sure how some has an accent that thick considering he has taught in Canada and the US for many years (according to him). Stumbles along through his speech as well, so makes it worse. You must listen intently. Overall a good prof though, fair and easy to do well.
Nice prof. Knowledgeable and helpful.However, very severe. Do not miss a class. Slides are not online and the course is not recorded. Fair marker.
Generouse prof, fun lectures, interesting course contents, I just loved taking the course. Excellent prof!! :D

Definitely one of the best profs I have had in the Cmns department.  Learned a lot and actually enjoyed going to class because he marks fairly easy and that made it easier to just come and engage with the material instead of worrying about grades ie. actually learned.

Lots of reading! Lectures are interesting. He speaks in a VERY academic, sophisticated way, which can be a little hard to keep up with if you are not a native speaker. Exams are very fair (open book, but you need to have your readings done nevertheless. Course material is very interesting, I felt like I learnt something valuable about the world.

IIRC, this was his 3rd semester teaching this course. He's an average prof who is organized in lectures, but is a mess when it comes to using Online Canvas. His exams are entirely based on the readings so be sure to read or else you won't be able to answer anything without it (it's open-book).

Super nice prof, like one of the best ones at SFU. If you were to talk to him, he's very easygoing and will change dates if the class agrees to it. First couple lectures are very interesting, but after that it was mostly group presentations which got a little dull. Overall, great prof and interesting course, I would take it again  :)

He's a very down to earth prof. Very easy to get along with because hes used to doing more grad classes than undergrad, so hes used to more interaction.  Makes material relatable to the real world and keeps it interesting.  his lectures relate closely to the readings. We had to all do a group presentation on one of the week's readings, was fine

When a student encounters a good prof, he/she will go on here and say "highly recommended" or things like that. But for Dr.Markwick, he deserves more than one highly. I Highly highly highly recommend him. The BEST prof at SFU! We had a lot of fun and many enjoyable conversations in class. SFU should offer him a lifetime contract!
